title: My Journey to Taming My Migraine Triggers

content: I was only 10 years old when I had my first migraine episode. For years, I had no clue what was causing the onset of my migraines. It felt like a random lottery. Would I wake up with a migraine today, or would I be migraine-free?

Then, I met a pediatrician who explained the concept of triggers to me. My pediatrician gave me a long list of possible triggers and sent me on a mission to discover what mine were. Here's what I discovered:

Sleep Schedule: It turns out that disrupting my sleep schedule was a guaranteed ticket to a migraine episode. Now, I prioritize a consistent sleep routine, even on weekends. Boring? Maybe. But it's way better than a throbbing head.
Food Culprits: Foods like dairy, gluten, sugar, corn, oats, and processed foods were sneaky migraine triggers for me. I switched my diet to eating clean and focusing on whole, unprocessed foods.

Travel Blues: Even though I am an avid traveler, sometimes a migraine and nausea are inevitable. Whether it's from stress or car sickness, it’s always important to be prepared for a travel-triggered migraine!

content_blocks.text: I was only 10 years old when I had my first migraine episode. For years, I had no clue what was causing the onset of my migraines. It felt like a random lottery. Would I wake up with a migraine today, or would I be migraine-free?

Then, I met a pediatrician who explained the concept of triggers to me. My pediatrician gave me a long list of possible triggers and sent me on a mission to discover what mine were. Here's what I discovered:

Sleep Schedule: It turns out that disrupting my sleep schedule was a guaranteed ticket to a migraine episode. Now, I prioritize a consistent sleep routine, even on weekends. Boring? Maybe. But it's way better than a throbbing head.
Food Culprits: Foods like dairy, gluten, sugar, corn, oats, and processed foods were sneaky migraine triggers for me. I switched my diet to eating clean and focusing on whole, unprocessed foods.

Travel Blues: Even though I am an avid traveler, sometimes a migraine and nausea are inevitable. Whether it's from stress or car sickness, it’s always important to be prepared for a travel-triggered migraine!

sections.heading: Fatigue Foe:
content: Pushing myself to the limit used to be my badge of honor. Now, I recognize the warning signs of fatigue and prioritize rest. It may mean missing out sometimes, but a little rest can go a long way.

Sensory Overload: An unfortunate trigger for me is over-stimulating environments. For example, the blaring music and flashing lights at concerts were a recipe for a migraine. Moving forward, I pack earplugs and noise-canceling headphones for crowded places.

While I may still get the occasional unwanted visitor, it's much less frequent now that I manage my triggers. Pay attention to your body's signals and what might be triggering your migraines. You might be surprised by the trigger culprits lurking in your life.
By understanding our triggers, we can take control and fight back against those pesky migraines!
Tap into a community of fellow migraineurs on Facebook. Learn, share, and connect in our Migraine Support Community .
Photo Credit: damircudic / E+ via Getty Images
